statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description: Tony Bethel emerged from a shooting slump by going 8-for-9 from the field and scoring 20 points, and No. 12 North Carolina State beat UNC-Greensboro 83-52.
article.headline: Bethel leads N.C. State to seventh consecutive win
article.linkText: Bethel leads N.C. State to seventh consecutive win
article.story: RALEIGH, N.C. (AP) -- With a victory over George Washington behind them and a game with archrival North Carolina ahead, North Carolina State coach Herb Sendek made it clear to his players not to take UNC-Greensboro for granted. No one heard that message any clearer than Tony Bethel. Emerging from a shooting slump, Bethel was 8-for-9 from the field and scored 20 points, and N.C. State (No. 12 ESPN/USA Today, No. 13 AP) used a 3-point flurry in the first half en route to an 83-52 victory Tuesday night. "In watching the tapes, I wasn't down in the stance on some of the shots I missed that I needed to make," Bethel said. "That's what helped me tonight. Once I get in a groove, I close my eyes and shoot it sometimes." The victory stretched N.C. State's winning streak to seven games, matching a similar run under Sendek in the 1999-2000 season, and it was the school's 10th straight win at home. The Wolfpack (12-1) matched the start in the 1988-89 season under the late Jim Valvano. The Spartans (7-7) were playing their second straight game against an Atlantic Coast Conference opponent. They took a 102-69 beating from top-ranked Duke last weekend, and the latest loss extended their losing streak to four games a posting a four-game winning streak. Bethel was in a 4-for-23 slide over the previous three games before finding his touch against the Spartans. He was 2-for-13 from 3-point range in that same stretch but hit 3-of-4 Tuesday. As for Sendek's worries about overlooking the Spartans less than a week after handing George Washington its first loss of the season, Bethel passed it off as typical. "That's how coaches always think," he said. "We knew what we needed to do, but with him being on top of us, we knew we needed to come out and get ready for UNC, basically, and I think we did a good job of that tonight." UNC-Greensboro tried a zone defense to offset matchup problems in the post, but N.C. State scuttled that strategy by shooting over it and hitting seven 3s in the first half. The Wolfpack finished 11-of-29 on 3-pointers. Cedric Simmons had 18 points for N.C. State, while Engin Atsur scored 13 of his 16 in the first half. Cameron Bennerman had 14 points for the Wolfpack, who shot 61 percent from the field. Kyle Hines led UNC-Greensboro with 18 points, and Ricky Hickman added 13. "We had the utmost respect for them coming in," Sendek said. "We talked about the fact that we had to come ready and play excellent basketball tonight. I don't think for even one-half a second our guys took UNCG lightly, not even for one-half second." Five straight points by Bethel gave the Wolfpack a 16-4 lead. Dwayne Johnson scored on a drive and Hickman completed a three-point play to put a speed bump in the Wolfpack's path, but Andrew Brackman's 3-pointer at 11:35 sparked a 12-2 N.C. State run that settled it. Atsur scored the last five points in that run. "We may have been a little tired," UNC-Greensboro coach Mike Dement said of the effect of the two-game stretch. "A little bit too much ACC for us right now. We need to see if we can regroup." Despite being outshot 55 percent to 50 percent, N.C. State led 46-27 at halftime. UNC-Greensboro got no closer than 18 points in the second half.
